verses.textEn: But he, as was the custom, extended the golden scepter with his hand, which was the sign of clemency, and she rose up and stood before him.
verses.textLa: At ille ex more sceptrum aureum protendit manu, quo signum clementiæ monstrabatur: illaque consurgens stetit ante eum,

verses.textEn: And she said, “If it pleases the king, and if I have found favor in his eyes, and my request is not seen to be disagreeable to him, I beg you that the former letters of Haman, the traitor and enemy of the Jews, by which he instructed them to be destroyed in all the king’s provinces, may be corrected by new letters.
verses.textLa: et ait: Si placet regi, et si inveni gratiam in oculis eius, et deprecatio mea non ei videtur esse contraria, obsecro, ut novis epistolis, veteres Aman litteræ, insidiatoris et hostis Iudæorum, quibus eos in cunctis regis provinciis perire præceperat, corrigantur.

verses.textEn: For how will I be able to endure the murder and execution of my people?”
verses.textLa: Quo modo enim potero sustinere necem et interfectionem populi mei?

verses.textEn: And king Artaxerxes answered Esther the queen and Mordecai the Jew, “I have granted Haman’s house to Esther, and I have ordered him to be fastened to a cross, because he dared to lay hands on the Jews.
verses.textLa: Responditque rex Assuerus Esther reginæ, et Mardochæo Iudæo: Domum Aman concessi Esther, et ipsum iussi affigi cruci, quia ausus est manum mittere in Iudæos.

verses.textEn: Therefore, write to the Jews, just as it pleases you, in the king’s name, sealing the letters with my ring.” For this was the custom, that letters which were sent in the king’s name and were sealed with his ring, no one would dare to contradict.
verses.textLa: Scribite ergo Iudæis, sicut vobis placet, regis nomine, signantes litteras annulo meo. Hæc enim consuetudo erat, ut epistolis, quæ ex regis nomine mittebantur, et illius annulo signatæ erant, nemo auderet contradicere.

verses.textEn: Then the scribes and copyists were brought in, (now it was the time of the third month which is called Sivan,) on the twenty-third day of the month, and letters were written, as Mordecai wanted, to the Jews, and to the governors, and procurators, and judges, who presided over the one hundred twenty-seven provinces, from India all the way to Ethiopia: to one province and another, to one people and another, in accordance with their languages and letters, and to the Jews, exactly as they were able to read and hear.
verses.textLa: Accitisque scribis et librariis regis (erat autem tempus tertii mensis, qui appellatur Siban) vigesima et tertia die illius scriptæ sunt epistolæ, ut Mardochæus voluerat, ad Iudæos, et ad principes, procuratoresque et iudices, qui centum vigintiseptem provinciis ab India usque ad Æthiopiam præsidebant: provinciæ atque provinciæ, populo et populo iuxta linguas et litteras suas, et Iudæis, prout legere poterant, et audire.
verses.notes: The scribes would translate the letter, and perhaps help to compose the letter. The copyists would write out copies of the letter, and perhaps even take dictation from the scribes as they translated.

verses.textEn: And these letters, which were sent in the king’s name, had been signed with his ring, and were sent by swift couriers who were to rush in every direction, through all the provinces, so as to prevent the former letters with new messages.
verses.textLa: Ipsæque epistolæ, quæ regis nomine mittebantur, annulo ipsius obsignatæ sunt, et missæ per veredarios: qui per omnes provincias discurrentes, veteres litteras novis nunciis prævenirent.
verses.notes: The word “veredarios” is derived from “veredus,” referring to a swift horse; veredarios refers to couriers using swift horses.

verses.textEn: The king commanded them to bring together the Jews throughout each city, and to instruct them to join together, so as to make a stand for their lives, and to execute and destroy all their enemies, with their wives and children and their entire houses, and to plunder their spoil.
verses.textLa: Quibus imperavit rex, ut convenirent Iudæos per singulas civitates, et in unum præciperent congregari ut starent pro animabus suis, et omnes inimicos suos cum coniugibus ac liberis et universis domibus, interficerent atque delerent, et spolia eorum diriperent.
verses.notes: The word “interficerent” refers to killing under authority, an execution rather than a murder.

verses.textEn: And one day of retribution was established throughout all the provinces, namely, the thirteenth of the twelfth month Adar.
verses.textLa: Et constituta est per omnes provincias una ultionis dies, id est tertiadecima mensis duodecimi Adar.

verses.textEn: “Artaxerxes, the great king from India all the way to Ethiopia, to the generals and leaders of the one hundred twenty-seven provinces that obey our command: greetings, he says.
verses.textLa: Rex magnus Artaxerxes ab India usque Æthiopiam centum vigintiseptem provinciarum ducibus ac principibus, qui nostræ iussioni obediunt, salutem dicit.

verses.textEn: In arrogance, many have abused the goodness of leaders and the honor that has been bestowed on them,
verses.textLa: Multi bonitate principum et honore, qui in eos collatus est, abusi sunt in superbiam:

verses.textEn: and they strive, not only to oppress the king’s subjects, but, not acting according to the glory given to them, set in motion a plan to ambush those very ones who gave it.
verses.textLa: et non solum subiectos regibus nituntur opprimere, sed datam sibi gloriam non ferentes, in ipsos, qui dederunt, moliuntur insidias.
verses.notes: The phrase “moliuntur insidias” is here translated loosely as “set in motion a plan to ambush.” The word moliuntur means to undertake something, or to labor or struggle to do something, or to set something (a plan) in motion. Insidias refers to treachery or a plot or an ambush.

verses.textEn: Neither are they content to withhold thanks for benefits and to violate in themselves the laws of humanity, but they also think they are able to escape from every sentence of the sifting judgment of God.
verses.textLa: Nec contenti sunt gratias non agere beneficiis, et humanitatis in se iura violare, sed Dei quoque cuncta cernentis arbitrantur se posse fugere sententiam.
verses.notes: The word cernentis means to sift or to distinguish or to discern. In this translation, the well-known phrase “sifting judgment of God” is fittingly applied.

verses.textEn: And they rush forth in such insanity that they attempt to subvert by filthy lies those who carefully fulfill the offices delegated to them and so perform everything that is deserving of the praise of all.
verses.textLa: Et in tantum vesaniæ proruperunt, ut eos, qui credita sibi officia diligenter observant, et ita cuncta agunt ut omnium laude digni sint, mendaciorum cuniculis conentur subvertere,
verses.notes: The phrase “mendaciorum cuniculis” is a very strong expression for a royal letter. The word “cuniculis” refers to excrement or filth, and can be a rather objectionable and base term.

verses.textEn: Meanwhile, they craftily deceive by fraud the ears of single-minded leaders, and they judge others according to their own nature.
verses.textLa: dum aures principum simplices, et ex sua natura alios æstimantes, callida fraude decipiunt.
verses.notes: The word “simplices” means simple or single or unaffected. In this context, “principum simplices” means a single-minded leader or a clear minded leader. The implication is that the leader does not bear much blame.

verses.textEn: These things are proven both from the ancient histories and from those things which happen daily: how the zeal of kings can be corrupted by the evil suggestions of such persons.
verses.textLa: Quæ res et ex veteribus probatur historiis, et ex his, quæ geruntur quotidie, quomodo malis quorumdam suggestionibus regum studia depraventur.

verses.textEn: Therefore, we will make provision for the peace of all the provinces.
verses.textLa: Unde providendum est paci omnium provinciarum.

verses.textEn: Neither should you think, if we change our orders, that they come from a fickle mind, but that we draw conclusions from the quality and necessity of the times, just as the expediency of the public good demands.
verses.textLa: Nec putare debetis, si diversa iubeamus, ex animi nostri venire levitate, sed pro qualitate et necessitate temporum, ut reipublicæ poscit utilitas, ferre sententiam.
verses.notes: Animi often means soul or life, but it can, as in this case, refer to the mind.

verses.textEn: And, so that you may more clearly understand what we are saying: Haman the son of Hammedatha, a Macedonian both in mind and ancestry, and foreign to Persian blood, and with his cruelty contaminating our piety, was accepted by us as a sojourner.
verses.textLa: Et ut manifestius quod dicimus, intelligatis, Aman filius Amadathi, et animo et gente Macedo, alienusque a Persarum sanguine, et pietatem nostram sua crudelitate commaculans, peregrinus a nobis susceptus est:
verses.notes: He was accepted as a sojourner, as a wayward traveler in need.

verses.textEn: And our humanity proved to be so great towards him that he was called our father and was adored by all as second only to the king.
verses.textLa: et tantam in se expertus humanitatem, ut pater noster vocaretur, et adoraretur ab omnibus post regem secundus:

verses.textEn: But he was so filled with arrogance as to strive to deprive us of our kingdom and our life.
verses.textLa: qui in tantum arrogantiæ tumorem sublatus est, ut regno privare nos niteretur et spiritu.

verses.textEn: For example, with certain strange and unheard of machinations, he sought the death of Mordecai, whose faith and kindness kept us alive, and Esther, the partner of our kingdom, and all their people.
verses.textLa: Nam Mardochæum, cuius fide et beneficiis vivimus, et consortem regni nostri Esther cum omni gente sua novis quibusdam atque inauditis machinis expetivit in mortem:

verses.textEn: This he planned so that, after they were executed, he might work treason against us in our solitude and transfer the kingdom of the Persians to the Macedonians.
verses.textLa: hoc cogitans ut illis interfectis, insidiaretur nostræ solitudini, et regnum Persarum transferret in Macedonas.

verses.textEn: But we, having been resolved to ruin in death the mortal Jews, discovered no fault within them, but on the contrary, they use just laws
verses.textLa: Nos autem a pessimo mortalium Iudæos neci destinatos, in nulla penitus culpa reperimus, sed e contrario iustis utentes legibus,
verses.notes: Clearly, the text is saying that the king had been resolved (destinatos, having been resolved) to kill the Jews, but changed his mind when he discovered no fault in them.

verses.textEn: and are sons of the highest and greatest and ever-living God, by whose kindness the kingdom was handed down both to our fathers and to us, and is cared for even unto this day.
verses.textLa: et filios altissimi et maximi, semperque viventis Dei, cuius beneficio et patribus nostris et nobis regnum est traditum, et usque hodie custoditur.

verses.textEn: Therefore, you should understand to be null and void those letters that he administered under our name.
verses.textLa: Unde eas litteras, quas sub nomine nostro ille direxerat, sciatis esse irritas.
verses.notes: The word “irritas” means “ineffective” or “null and void.”

verses.textEn: For this crime, before the gates of this city, that is, Susa, both he who devised it, and all his associates, hang on gallows: not we, but God repaying him as he deserved.
verses.textLa: Pro quo scelere ante portas huius urbis, id est, Susan, et ipse qui machinatus est, et omnis cognatio eius pendet in patibulis: non nobis, sed Deo reddente ei quod meruit.
verses.notes: The word “cognatio” often refers to relatives, but it can include close friends or close associates.

verses.textEn: But this edict, which we now send, shall be displayed in all cities so that the Jews may be allowed to use their own laws.
verses.textLa: Hoc autem edictum, quod nunc mittimus, in cunctis urbibus proponatur, ut liceat Iudæis uti legibus suis.

verses.textEn: You must be a support to them, so that they may be able to execute those, who themselves had prepared to kill them, on the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, which is called Adar.
verses.textLa: Quibus debetis esse adminiculo, ut eos, qui se ad necem eorum paraverant, possint interficere tertiadecima die mensis duodecimi, qui vocatur Adar.
verses.notes: Notice that the act of the Jews killing their enemies is called an execution (interficere, to kill by authority), whereas the act of their enemies planning to kill the Jews is called a killing or murder (necem). The author’s choice of words show the understanding that this act by the Jews is lawful, whereas the act planned by Haman, though done under the guise of authority, was unlawful.

verses.textEn: For the almighty God has turned this day of grief and sorrow into joy for them.
verses.textLa: Hanc enim diem, Deus omnipotens, mœroris et luctus, eis vertit in gaudium.
verses.notes: Again, the verb vertit is used to indicate the change of fortune of the Jews.

verses.textEn: Therefore, you too will keep this day, along with the other festival days, and celebrate it with all joy, so that it may be known even by future generations.
verses.textLa: Unde et vos inter ceteros festos dies, hanc habetote diem, et celebrate eam cum omni lætitia, ut et in posterum cognoscatur,
verses.notes: Or, by (your) posterity.

verses.textEn: All those who faithfully obey the Persians deserve, for their fidelity, to receive a reward, but those who are traitors to their kingdom deserve to be destroyed for their crime.
verses.textLa: omnes, qui fideliter Persis obediunt, dignam pro fide recipere mercedem: qui autem insidiantur regno eorum, perire pro scelere.

verses.textEn: But every province and city, which is not willing to participate in this solemnity, must perish by the sword and by fire, and be destroyed in this way so that they will be forever an indisputable example of contempt and disobedience, not only to humans, but even to wild animals.”
verses.textLa: Omnis autem provincia et civitas, quæ noluerit sollemnitatis huius esse particeps, gladio et igne pereat, et sic deleatur, ut non solum hominibus, sed etiam bestiis invia sit in sempiternum, pro exemplo contemptus, et inobedientiæ.
verses.notes: The word “invia” means impassable or inaccessible, but in this context, it refers to something that one cannot ignore or explain away, i.e., something intellectually impassable or indisputable.

verses.textEn: And such was the content of the letter, so that it would be made known in all lands and nations, which are subject to the authority of king Artaxerxes, that the Jews have been made ready to be vindicated of their enemies.
verses.textLa: Summaque epistolæ hæc fuit, ut in omnibus terris ac populis, qui regis Assueri subiacebant imperio, notum fieret, paratos esse Iudæos ad capiendam vindictam de hostibus suis.

verses.textEn: And so the swift couriers departed in haste, carrying through the announcement, and the king’s edict was hung up in Susa.
verses.textLa: Egressique sunt veredarii celeres nuncia perferentes, et edictum regis pependit in Susan.

verses.textEn: But Mordecai, going forth from the palace and from the king’s presence, shone in royal apparel the color of hyacinth and of the sky, wearing a golden crown on his head, and clothed with a cloak of silk and purple. And all the city rejoiced and was joyful.
verses.textLa: Mardochæus autem de palatio, et de conspectu regis egrediens, fulgebat vestibus regiis, hyacinthinis videlicet et aeriis, coronam auream portans in capite, et amictus serico pallio atque purpureo. Omnisque civitas exultavit, atque lætata est.

verses.textEn: But for the Jews, a new light seemed to rise; there was joy, honor, and dancing.
verses.textLa: Iudæis autem nova lux oriri visa est, gaudium, honor, et tripudium.
verses.notes: Or, more loosely: “But the Jews saw a new light rise....”

verses.textEn: With all the peoples, cities, and provinces, wherever the king’s orders arrived, there was wonderful rejoicing, banquets and feasts, and a solemn holy day, so much so that many of the other nations joined themselves to their religious practices and ceremonies. For a great fear of the name of the Jews had overcome them all.
verses.textLa: Apud omnes populos, urbes, atque provincias, quocumque regis iussa veniebant, mira exultatio, epulæ atque convivia, et festus dies: in tantum ut plures alterius gentis et sectæ eorum religioni et ceremoniis iungerentur. Grandis enim cunctos Iudaici nominis terror invaserat.

verses.textEn: Therefore, on the thirteenth day of the twelfth month, which as we have said before is called Adar, when all the Jews were prepared to be executed and their enemies were greedy for their blood, the situation turned around, and the Jews began to have the upper hand and to vindicate themselves of their adversaries.
verses.textLa: Igitur duodecimi mensis, quem Adar vocari ante iam diximus, tertiadecima die, quando cunctis Iudæis interfectio parabatur, et hostes eorum inhiabant sanguini, versa vice Iudæi superiores esse cœperunt, et se de adversariis vindicare.
verses.notes: “Versa vice” means, literally, “around turn.”

verses.textEn: And they gathered together throughout each city, and town, and place, so as to extend their hands against their enemies and their persecutors. And no one dared to resist them, because their great power had pierced all the peoples.
verses.textLa: Congregatique sunt per singulas civitates, oppida, et loca ut extenderent manum contra inimicos, et persecutores suos. Nullusque ausus est resistere, eo quod omnes populos magnitudinis eorum formido penetrarat.

verses.textEn: For even the judges of the provinces, and the rulers, and the procurators, and everyone of dignity, who presided over every place and work, extolled the Jews for fear of Mordecai.
verses.textLa: Nam et provinciarum iudices, et duces, et procuratores, omnisque dignitas, quæ singulis locis ac operibus præerat, extollebant Iudæos timore Mardochæi:

verses.textEn: For they knew him to be the leader of the palace and to have much power. Likewise, the fame of his name increased daily and flew everywhere through word of mouth.
verses.textLa: quem principem esse palatii, et plurimum posse cognoverant: fama quoque nominis eius crescebat quotidie, et per cunctorum ora volitabat.

verses.textEn: And so the Jews struck their enemies like a great plague and killed them, repaying according to what they had prepared to do to them,
verses.textLa: Itaque percusserunt Iudæi inimicos suos plaga magna, et occiderunt eos, reddentes eis quod sibi paraverant facere:

verses.textEn: so much so that even in Susa they executed five hundred men, besides the ten sons of Haman the Agagite, the enemy of the Jews, and their names are these:
verses.textLa: in tantum ut etiam in Susan quingentos viros interficerent, extra decem filios Aman Agagitæ hostis Iudæorum: quorum ista sunt nomina:

verses.textEn: Parshandatha, and Dalphon, and Aspatha
verses.textLa: Pharsandatha, et Delphon, et Esphatha,

verses.textEn: and Poratha, and Adalia, and Aridatha,
verses.textLa: et Phoratha, et Adalia, et Aridatha,

verses.textEn: and Parmashta, and Arisai, and Aridai, and Vaizatha.
verses.textLa: et Phermesta et Arisai, et Aridai, et Iezatha.

verses.textEn: When they had slain them, they were unwilling to touch the spoils of their belongings.
verses.textLa: Quos cum occidissent, prædas de substantiis eorum tangere noluerunt.
verses.notes: Or, the spoils of their necessities.

verses.textEn: And immediately the number of those who had been killed in Susa was reported to the king.
verses.textLa: Statimque numerus eorum, qui occisi erant in Susan, ad regem relatus est.

verses.textEn: He said to the queen, “In the city of Susa, the Jews have executed five hundred men, and also the ten sons of Haman. How many executions do you think that they have carried out in all the provinces? What more do you ask, and what do you wish, so that I may order it to be done?”
verses.textLa: Qui dixit reginæ: In urbe Susan interfecerunt Iudæi quingentos viros, et alios decem filios Aman: quantam putas eos exercere cædem in universis provinciis? Quid ultra postulas, et quid vis ut fieri iubeam?

verses.textEn: And she answered, “If it pleases the king, may power be granted to the Jews, so as to do tomorrow in Susa just as they have done today, and that the ten sons of Haman may be hung up the gallows.”
verses.textLa: Cui illa respondit: Si regi placet, detur potestas Iudæis, ut sicut fecerunt hodie in Susan, sic et cras faciant, et decem filii Aman in patibulis suspendantur.
verses.notes: The sons of Haman are “hung up” on the gallows, not “hanged” on the gallows. The word hanged implies that someone is being put to death, whereas hung merely means suspended. In the next verse, the edict and the sons of Haman are both hung up, each as a kind of public notice of these events.

verses.textEn: And the king instructed that it should be so done. And immediately the edict was hung up in Susa, and the ten sons of Haman were hung up.
verses.textLa: Præcepitque rex ut ita fieret. Statimque in Susan pependit edictum, et decem filii Aman suspensi sunt.

verses.textEn: On the fourteenth day of the month Adar, the Jews gathered themselves together, and they executed in Susa three hundred men, but they did not seize their belongings from them.
verses.textLa: Congregatis Iudæis quartadecima die mensis Adar, interfecti sunt in Susan trecenti viri: nec eorum ab illis direpta substantia est.

verses.textEn: Moreover, throughout all the provinces which were subject to the king’s dominion, the Jews made a stand for their lives, and they executed their enemies and their persecutors, so much so that the number of those who were killed amounted to seventy-five thousand, and yet no one touched any of their belongings.
verses.textLa: Sed et per omnes provincias, quæ ditioni regis subiacebant, pro animabus suis steterunt Iudæi, interfectis hostibus ac persecutoribus suis: in tantum ut septuagintaquinque millia occisorum implerentur, et nullus de substantiis eorum quidquam contingeret.
verses.notes: The phrase “pro animabus suis steterunt” means that they stood up on behalf of their souls or their lives.

verses.textEn: Now the thirteenth day of the month Adar was the first day with all of the executions, and on the fourteenth day they ceased the killing. This day they established to be sacred, so that in all times hereafter they would be free for feasting, joyfulness, and celebration.
verses.textLa: Dies autem tertiusdecimus mensis Adar primus apud omnes interfectionis fuit, et quartadecima die cædere desierunt. Quem constituerunt esse sollemnem, ut in eo omni tempore deinceps vacarent epulis, gaudio atque conviviis.

verses.textEn: But, as for those who were carrying out the killings in the city of Susa, they turned to killing on the thirteenth and fourteenth day of the same month. But on the fifteenth day they ceased to attack. And for that reason they established that day as sacred, with feasting and with gladness.
verses.textLa: At hi, qui in urbe Susan cædem exercuerant, tertiodecimo et quartodecimo die eiusdem mensis in cæde versati sunt: quintodecimo autem die percutere desierunt. Et idcirco eundem diem constituerunt sollemnem epularum atque lætitiæ.
verses.notes: The expression “turned to killing” (in cæde versati sunt) refers to the Jews turning the killing upon those who would have killed them. A day that was originally supposed to be a disastrous day for the Jews became a day of vindication for them, so that circumstances were turned around for them.

verses.textEn: But in truth, those Jews who were staying in unwalled towns and villages, appointed the fourteenth day of the month Adar for celebration and gladness, so as to rejoice on that day and send one another portions of their feasts and their meals.
verses.textLa: Hi vero Iudæi, qui in oppidis non muratis ac villis morabantur, quartumdecimum diem mensis Adar conviviorum et gaudii decreverunt, ita ut exultent in eo, et mittant sibi mutuo partes epularum et ciborum.
verses.notes: “Epularum” is food in the sense of feasting, special holiday foods. “Ciborum” is food in the sense of daily sustenance, that is, staple foods. They sent one another both types of foods.

verses.textEn: And so Mordecai wrote down all these things and sent them, composed in letters, to the Jews who were staying in all the king’s provinces, as much to those in nearby places as to those far away,
verses.textLa: Scripsit itaque Mardochæus omnia hæc, et litteris comprehensa misit ad Iudæos, qui in omnibus regis provinciis morabantur, tam in vicino positis, quam procul,

verses.textEn: so that they would accept the fourteenth and fifteenth day of the month Adar for holy days, and always, at the return of the year, would celebrate them with sacred esteem.
verses.textLa: ut quartamdecimam et quintamdecimam diem mensis Adar pro festis susciperent, et revertente semper anno sollemni celebrarent honore:

verses.textEn: For on those days, the Jews vindicated themselves of their enemies, and their mourning and sorrow were turned into mirth and joy, so that these would be days of feasting and gladness, in which they would send one another portions of their feasts, and would grant gifts to the poor.
verses.textLa: quia in ipsis diebus se ulti sunt Iudæi de inimicis suis, et luctus atque tristitia in hilaritatem gaudiumque conversa sunt, essentque dies isti epularum atque lætitiæ, et mitterent sibi invicem ciborum partes, et pauperibus munuscula largirentur.

verses.textEn: And the Jews accepted as a solemn ritual all the things which they had begun to do at that time, which Mordecai had commanded with letters to be done.
verses.textLa: Susceperuntque Iudæi in sollemnem ritum cuncta quæ eo tempore facere cœperant, et quæ Mardochæus litteris facienda mandaverat.

verses.textEn: For Haman, the son of Hammedatha of Agag lineage, the enemy and adversary of the Jews, had devised evil against them, to kill them and to destroy them. And he had cast Pur, which in our language means the lot.
verses.textLa: Aman enim, filius Amadathi stirpis Agag, hostis et adversarius Iudæorum, cogitavit contra eos malum, ut occideret illos, atque deleret: et misit phur, quod nostra lingua vertitur in sortem.

verses.textEn: And after this, Esther had entered before the king, begging him that his efforts might be made ineffective by the king’s letters, and that the evil he intended against the Jews might return upon his own head. Finally, both he and his sons were fastened to a cross.
verses.textLa: Et postea ingressa est Esther ad regem, obsecrans ut conatus eius, litteris regis irriti fierent: et malum, quod contra Iudæos cogitaverat, reverteretur in caput eius. Denique et ipsum et filios eius affixerunt cruci,

verses.textEn: And so, from that time, these days are called Purim, that is, of the lots, because Pur, that is, the lot, was cast into the urn. And all things that had been carried out are contained in the volume of this epistle, that is, of this book.
verses.textLa: atque ex illo tempore dies isti appellati sunt phurim, id est sortium: eo quod phur, id est sors, in urnam missa fuerit. Et cuncta, quæ gesta sunt, epistolæ, id est libri huius volumine continentur:

verses.textEn: And whatever they suffered, and whatever was altered afterwards, the Jews received for themselves and their offspring and for all who were willing to be joined to their religion, so that none would be permitted to transgress the solemnity of these two days, to which the writing testifies, and which certain times require, as the years continually succeed one another.
verses.textLa: quæque sustinuerunt, et quæ deinceps immutata sunt, susceperunt Iudæi super se et semen suum, et super cunctos, qui religioni eorum voluerunt copulari, ut nulli liceat duos hos dies absque sollemnitate transigere: quos scriptura testatur, et certa expetunt tempora, annis sibi iugiter succedentibus.

verses.textEn: These are the days which no one ever will erase into oblivion, and which every province in the whole world, throughout each generation, shall celebrate. Neither is there any city wherein the days of Purim, that is, of lots, may not be observed by the Jews, and by their posterity, which has been obligated to these ceremonies.
verses.textLa: Isti sunt dies, quos nulla umquam delebit oblivio: et per singulas generationes cunctæ in toto orbe provinciæ celebrabunt: nec est ulla civitas, in qua dies phurim, id est sortium, non observentur a Iudæis, et ab eorum progenie, quæ his ceremoniis obligata est.

verses.textEn: And Esther the queen, the daughter of Abihail, and Mordecai the Jew, also wrote a second letter, so that with all zealousness this day would be confirmed as customary for future generations.
verses.textLa: Scripseruntque Esther regina filia Abihail, et Mardochæus Iudæus etiam secundam epistolam, ut omni studio dies ista solemnis sanciretur in posterum:

verses.textEn: And they sent to all the Jews, who had been stirred up in the one hundred twenty-seven provinces of king Artaxerxes, that they should have peace and receive truth,
verses.textLa: et miserunt ad omnes Iudæos, qui in centum viginti septem provinciis regis Assueri versabantur, ut haberent pacem, et susciperent veritatem,

verses.textEn: and observe the days of lots, and celebrate them with joy at their proper time, just as Mordecai and Esther had established. And they accepted these to be observed by themselves and by their offspring: fasting, and crying out, and the days of lots,
verses.textLa: observantes dies sortium, et suo tempore cum gaudio celebrarent: sicut constituerant Mardochæus et Esther, et illi observanda susceperunt a se, et a semine suo ieiunia, et clamores, et sortium dies,

verses.textEn: and all things which are contained in the history of this book, which is called Esther.
verses.textLa: et omnia, quæ libri huius, qui vocatur Esther, historia continentur.

verses.textEn: Truly, king Artaxerxes made all the land, and all the islands of the sea, tributaries.
verses.textLa: Rex vero Assuerus omnem terram, et cunctas maris insulas fecit tributarias:
verses.notes: Or, he made a tribute, i.e., he collected a tribute from all the lands and islands.

verses.textEn: And his strength and his authority, and the dignity and supremacy with which he exalted Mordecai, have been written in the books of the Medes and the Persians,
verses.textLa: cuius fortitudo et imperium, et dignitas atque sublimitas, qua exaltavit Mardochæum, scripta sunt in libris Medorum, atque Persarum:

verses.textEn: and how Mordecai of Jewish birth, was second after king Artaxerxes, and great among the Jews, and acceptable to the people of his brethren, seeking the good of his people, and speaking about things which pertained to peace for their descendants.
verses.textLa: et quomodo Mardochæus Iudaici generis secundus a rege Assuero fuerit: et magnus apud Iudæos et acceptabilis plebi fratrum suorum, quærens bona populo suo, et loquens ea, quæ ad pacem seminis sui pertinerent.

verses.textEn: And Mordecai said, “By God have these things been done.
verses.textLa: Dixitque Merdochæus: A Deo facta sunt ista.

verses.textEn: I remember a dream that I saw, which signified these same things, and nothing of this whatsoever has failed to occur.
verses.textLa: Recordatus sum somnii, quod videram, hæc eadem significantis: nec eorum quidquam irritum fuit.

verses.textEn: The little fountain which grew into a river, and had turned into light and into the sun, and overflowed into many waters, is Esther, whom the king received as wife and whom he preferred to be queen.
verses.textLa: Parvus fons, qui crevit in fluvium, et in lucem, solemque conversus est, et in aquas plurimas redundavit: Esther est, quam rex accepit uxorem, et voluit esse reginam.

verses.textEn: But the two dragons are I and Haman.
verses.textLa: Duo autem dracones: ego sum, et Aman.

verses.textEn: The peoples who gathered together are those who had attempted to erase the name of the Jews.
verses.textLa: Gentes, quæ convenerant: hi sunt, qui conati sunt delere nomen Iudæorum.

verses.textEn: And my people is Israel, who cried out to the Lord, and the Lord brought salvation to his people, and he freed us from all evils, and he created great signs and portents among the nations.
verses.textLa: Gens autem mea: Israel est, quæ clamavit ad Dominum, et salvum fecit Dominus populum suum: liberavitque nos ab omnibus malis, et fecit signa magna atque portenta inter Gentes:

verses.textEn: And he commanded there to be two lots, one for the people of God and the other for all the nations.
verses.textLa: et duas sortes esse præcepit, unam Populi Dei, et alteram cunctarum Gentium.
verses.notes: The command that there be two lots means that there would be two different fates or two different end results, one for the people of God and the other for the nations.

verses.textEn: And both lots arrived at the day appointed before God, even from that past time, for all peoples.
verses.textLa: Venitque utraque sors in statutum ex illo iam tempore diem coram Deo universis gentibus:
verses.notes: Both end results are completed at the same time: the vindication of the people of God and the punishment of their enemies.

verses.textEn: And the Lord remembered his people and had mercy on his inheritance.
verses.textLa: et recordatus est Dominus populi sui, ac misertus est hereditatis suæ.

verses.textEn: And these days shall be observed in the month of Adar, on the fourteenth and fifteenth day of the same month, with all zealousness and joy, by the people gathered together into one union, throughout all the generations hereafter of the people of Israel.”
verses.textLa: Et observabuntur dies isti in mense Adar quartadecima, et quintadecima die eiusdem mensis, cum omni studio, et gaudio in unum cœtum populi congregati, in cunctas deinceps generationes populi Israel.

verses.textEn: In the fourth year of the reigns of Ptolemy and Cleopatra, Dositheus, who was himself a priest and born of the Levites, and Ptolemy his son, brought this epistle of Purim, which they said was a translation by Lysimachus the son of Ptolemy in Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Anno quarto regnantibus Ptolemæo, et Cleopatra, attulerunt Dosithæus, qui se Sacerdotem, et Levitici generis ferebat, et Ptolemæus filius eius hanc epistolam phurim, quam dixerunt interpretatum esse Lysimachum Ptolemæi filium in Ierusalem.
verses.notes: The phrase “qui se Sacerdotem” is often translated as “who said he was a priest” or “who claimed he was a priest.” But the word “se” does not indicate that this man claimed something; it is merely a reflexive pronoun, a way of emphasizing that this man “was himself a priest.”
